div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Legislative Council. ——The Legislative Council will hold a meeting on ‘Thursday next.
Quarantine. ——“Arrivals from Egyptian ports at Cyprus are subjected to medical inspection.
Council of Ministers. ——The Council of Ministers will assemble to-morrow at San Stephano under the presidency of Hussain Fakhri Pasha, Regent.

Murder of an English Fireman. ——The Italian and Greek ‘‘softeners,” accused of being concerned in the death of a fireman from an English merchant vessel, in Alex-Andria, are now in prison pending their trials.
Drowning Fatality. ——A native mason fell from the -ferry boat plying between Old Cairo and Gheimeh on Friday about 11 o’clock and was drowned. The body was recovered after an hour's search.

Dredger “ St. Giles.” —— The Admiralty dredger “St. Giles” which was for sometime engaged in the harbor works here has arrived at Alexandria from Devon-port. It was’ rumored here that the “St Giles” had come to grief on her voyage home, but she met with no misadventure.

Bahr e! Chazal. ——The Governor of Bahr el Ghazal no longer undertakes to arrange for the transport of parcels of Government employees in the Burh-el-Ghazal Province as heretofore. Government employees must make their own arrangements in this connection. ‘The Post and 'Telegraphs Department only accepts parcels addressed for delivery in Mishra, or in WA when the Jury River is open and notice has been given to hat to effect.

Fire at Omdurman. —— A fire broke out last week in two shops of the new Sirdar Street at Omdurman. ‘The policemen who arrived upon the scene found themselves unable to extinguish the fire as the only well in the neighborhood had no bucket. Mr. Kami, however, opened his house to them and invited ‘them to use his pumps which- helped: to extinguish the flames. Fortunately no one was injured and the damage done was not ‘considerable.

Carlo’s Collapsed House —— A further portion of, the house which collapsed in Sharia Mohamed Aly has fallen and three rooms fell through with a terrific crash on Friday. Suffocating dust arose and the tram service was stopped for about half an hour. A subscription list has been opened for the help of the sufferers and it is to be hoped that liberal support will be given to those poor. persons who have found themselves homeless.

Death by Drink. —— On Friday evening about 9 o'clock a Nero-peen was discovered on the pavement in a Cairo street in an advanced state of intoxicant-tin. On being conveyed to the caracul he muttered some words supposed to. have been in Italian. The officer on duty caused the man to be conveyed to the hospital, but he expired almost immediately on arrival there. The Italian Consulate has been advised of the occurrence in order to ascertain the man’s identity.

div.head: A BELATED ANNOUNCEMENT
div.p: Information regarding the trend of events in this country seems to travel very slowly to some parts. Of Europe, judging by a pa- trigraph, which appears in a recent issue of a Cologne newspaper. According to this journal “the idea is gaining ground in Egypt that the National Bank of Egypt must be transformed into a State bank. The large exporters of cotton will son require consider- rabble sums, and if these are not available at the right moment the whole of the pro- tits of the harvest will not be obtained, a matter which would have serious consequences- Wes to the economic life of Egypt. A State bank is needed, the Cologne newspaper sat- test, which would fundamentally support the export trade. in ‘cotton. That the suggestion is approved in high quarters is shown by the issue of a recent decree sanctioning the emission of shares by the National Bank of the nominal value of £500,000, and this, too, at a time when new foundations and a capital augmentations are regarded with skepticism.”

In view of the frequent references to the negotiations for the conversion of the National Bank into a State institution which have appeared in the “Gazette” and other journalist during the past twelve months the above announcement may not unreason- nobly he described as “late.”

div.head: BRIDGE-AT KHARTOUM.
div.p: Mr. MacNeil! asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether a bridge over the Nile at Khartoum was to be constructed at a cost of £250,000; whether a contract for the construction had yet been given to any and what firm; and, if not, whether it might be tendered for by open competition.
Sir E. Grey: I’ll make inquiries about this.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Messrs. P. Henderson & Co’s. 8.8. “Irrawaddy” now in port, will sail on Wednesday. next for Dover, This fine steamer has still ascoma- (lotion for a few more passengers : fare £10-0-0.
The Papa Yanni liner “Arabian” arrived from Glasgow, Liverpool, Gibraltar, Tangiers and Malta with passengers and mails this morning.

div.head: FUNERAL OF DECEASED OFFICERS.
div.p: At the inquest held on Saturday before Mr. F. G. Freeman, H.B.M’s Vice-Consul, at Ras el Tin hospital, it was proved that the sad accident, by which Captains Stokes and. Carey lost their lives, took place between 4.30 and 5.0 p.m, In his evidence Captain Crawley, A.S.C., stated that hearing a noise at about 5 p.m. he looked from the balcony of the Beau Rivage Hotel and saw Capt. Carey swimming against the current, and making little or no progress Stokes having disappeared. Hearing him call for help Capt. Crawley ran to the beach, took his coat off, and went in getting to within five or six yards of the swimmer, when the current carried him away to the east. He made a second attempt, this time with a rope, and was himself carried under, and had to be hauled ashore, when Capt. Carey had disap-peared. The other evidence dealt mainly with the attempts at restoring animation in the ease of Capt. Carey, which appear to have been persevered with as long as there was any hope. The jury which consisted of Messrs. J. T. Atkin, J. Gunn, and C. D. Stacey gave a verdict in accordance with the evidence, and recorded their hearty commendation of Capt. Crawley’s courageous attempt at a rescue.

At 5 p.m. on Saturday the military funeral started from the Bourse. Shortly before that hour a strong detachment of the 2nd Royal Inniskillking Fusiliers had,arrived by special train from Cairo, and marched to the square, where it was mot by the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment, ‘i he procession was preceded by the Egyptian mounted police, who kept the streets clear as far as the Rosetta gate. The military mounted police led the long column, followed by the band of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment, which played the Dead March. The two gun carriages, which conveyed the bodies to their resting place were draped with the Union Jack, and we were glad to note that almost all the Europeans and Syrians who were present— and the cortege passed through crowded streets —sainted the dead. General Bullock, Maj. Ludlow.D.A.A.G., Admiral Sir R M. Blomfield, and several of the principal members of the Head Quarters staff, representatives of the Governorat and the Egyptian Army, and severa! Well known members of the Consular Body and the British community followed. The Iunis-killings detachment, and the 2nd Royal Berkshires brought up the rear. At the Rosetta gate the procession was joined by the firing party, and the two bands of the Inniskillings who played the Dead March as far as the cemetery. The Rev. A. H. Manning, acting-Chaplain to the forces, conducted the burial service by the grave, where a number of beautiful wreaths had been laid by the comrades and friends of the deceased. The coffins were carried into the cemetery by the. sergeants and staff sergeants of the Inniskiliing Fusiliers. On the conclusions of the burial service, the usual volleys were fired over the grave, and the general salute to the dead, and the "Last Post” brought the sad ceremony to an end

The following special army order has been issued from the Headquarters, Cairo ‘It is with profound regret that the General Officer Commanding announces the deaths of Captain E. S. Carey, Adjutant, 2nd Bn. Royal Innis-killing Fusiliers and of Captain C. H. G. V. Stokes, 2nd Bn Royal Inniskiliing Fusiliers, who were accidentally drowned while bathing at Alexandria on 11th August. Both these Officers did distinguished service during the late war, and the Server sustains a great loss by their untimely
THE HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE.

We mentioned in a recent issue that the above company, which has taken Over the business of Mr. Stangen, the well known German tourist agent, contemplated starting a river passenger service between Cairo and Assouan during the tourist season of 1906-7, to compete with the old established lines of Messrs. Cook and Son, and the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company. Later it was announced that negotiations had been to entered into between the latte and the Hamburg-Amerika Company to work the two services in conjunction. It appears, from what we now learn, that the negotiations between the two companies are still in progress, and there is every reason to believe that a satisfactory arrangement will be arrived at sood. Several meetings have already taken place in Europe between the representatives of both sides, but nothing definite has yet been decided.

div.head: CONSTANTINOPLE OUTRAGE
another Theory.
div.p: We have been shown a letter from a British resident in Constantinople which gives the following news of the bomb outrage against H.I.M. the Sultan. "in a country like this, where nothing in the shape of public meetings is allowed, interest,even in such an occurrence, dies down very quickly. It is, generally speak-ing, dangerous for an ordinary Turk to talk politics, excepting in the privacy of his own house, where, it is to be presumed, no members of the Khafieh are present. Consequently there has been no public display of indignation—or of approbation-and all that I get from peasants, boatmen, and the like, is—“We think it was an Armenian, but, please, may we change the subjeot ?” Preposterous stories were current about the extent of the casualties, many supposing that at least 1,000 persons were disposed of. As a matter of fact, I think, seventeen were killed and forty odd wonnded. The Saltan behaved quite coolly, realising that the danger to his person was passed, and keeping off the crowd of officers and ministers that gathered round him; as much, I fancy, from a desire to avoid another attack with cold steel, as to stop the panic. The police scoured the town, arrested several hundreds of harmless folk, and sent back to their homes as many Armenians and Bulgars not domiciled here, as they could find. They have, as yet, hit on no clue worth anything, though they got up a yam about an india-rubber tyred carriage, which has appeared in all the papers. Many of the best-informed residents think it more probable that the outrage was the work of plotters at the palace—perhaps of the Albanian body guard, who are terribly out of hand at present. Of course the revolutionaries, Armenians and Macedonians, took the “oredit” for a cruel and clumsy outrage, and the police are only too glad to be spared the trouble of ferreting about among the secretaries and chamberlains at Yildiz Kiosk, some of whom are disaffected scoundrels.”
SHOCKING SUICIDE IN CAIRO

A French gentleman, of the name of Emile Jullien, committed suicide yesterday morning by jumping from a third floor balcony into the street. He sustained frightful injuries to the head, and death was almost instantaneous. The deceased, who lived at the Maison Sabbagh, in the Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, with his brother and his family, had been suffering for over a year from melancholia which, at times, assumed an acute form. This was the case on Saturday night, when he was carefully watched. He ran twice to the balcony early in the morning with the intention of jumping over, and was prevented, hot the third time he succeeded in evading his watchers, and accomplished his purpose. The late Monsieur Emile Jullien was a batchelor of 39 years of age, and had formerly been employed at the local Mixed Tribunals.

div.head: The Nile FLOOD.
MR. WEBB’S Report
div.p: In my last note I pointed out the following, viz (a) that the levels of the river had been unprecedently low from the middle of May, and that the irrigation of the summer crops had only been rendered possible by the supplementary supply derived from the Assouan-Reservoir. (b) That the flood was very late in its earlier stages, and promised to be low.

The Assouan Reservoir was emptied on 20th July (one month later than in 1904), since which date the supply in the river has been maintained by the flood, which reached Assouan nearly one month later than the usual time, and then not in sufficient quantity to satisfy the demands for the irrigation of the “sharaki” durah lands as well as the cotton crops, so that it will be found necessary to maintain the canals in the Delta and Middle Egypt until probably the middle of this month.

The rice crop, has, naturally, suffered in many places, but the cotton crop has been entirely saved by the Assouan Reservoir. Both in the Delta and Middle Egypt it is stated to be most excellent, and unless unfavorable climatic conditions prevail in September next, the crop should be a record one. The Cotton worm has been practically extirpated, owing to the very energetic and successful measures organised by the Ministry of Interior.

The irrigation of the “sharaki" durah lands has been somewhat retarded, but is in advance of the years previous to the construction of the weir below the Delta Barrage and the Assiout Barrage : the delay has caused com plaint, bat it is doubtful if any real damage has been done. It may be noted that in 1899, the irrigation of “sharaki” durah lands was not allowed until the 6th August in the Delta, whilst in the present year it was allowed 10 days earlier. Owing to the rise now taking place the irrigation of all crops in the Delta and Middle Egypt is absolutely assured, and no further anxiety need be felt throughout the flood. Regulation is being carried on both at the Delta, Zifta and Assiout Barrages; the latter will be completely closed within the next few days.

It may interesting to note that op to date not a drop of water has passed down the two branches of the Nile into the sea. The “sadd” in the Rosetta branch, however, is not likely to stand more than a few days longer. This fact, alone, shows how very late the flood has been, and how usefuls the barrages have been in utilising every drop of water available.
At Khartoum.—The following table gives a comparison of the gauges at Khartoum for 1905, last year, and the two very low years, 1899 and 1902, viz :—

It will be seen from the above that the levels are 1.50 metres below those of last year, which wan by no means a good year, and 25 to 30 centimetres below those of 1899 and 1902, both yearn of extremely low floods. The Hood In the While Nile has been fairly normal that it the Blue Nile completely failed. Captain Lyons, who has most skilfully and so entifically studied the question, states that there wan great deficiency in the rains in Abyssinia during May and June, that in July matters improved, and “that it seems probable that, so far as indications show, the August rains are more likely to be poor than good." The prospects therefore, are not promising,and although a rise has lately taken place on the Blue Nile and the Atbara, the present indication is that the flood of this year will follow that of 1902.

div.head: Passenger Lists
div.p: Departures
Arrivals

From the above it will be seen that the Assouan gauge is now 2.74 metres below last year and 3.01 metres below the average of the last 30 years. Taking into consideration the rise south of Assouan, now taking place, it is probable that the flood of this year will follow that of 1902. According to the rules of the Public Works Ministry, a “bad Nile” is declared when the Assouan gauge does not reach 13 pics on the 15th August; as there is no possibility of this occurring, the Ministry has decided to declare a “bad Nile” at once, and instructions have been issued to take the same measures as were carried out to meet he low flood of 1902. The area of “sharaki” in 1902 was 128,000 feddana, and, unless conditions rapidly improve, it is quite probable that the same area may remain unirrigated by the present flood.

Summary —In the Delta and Middle Egypt the irrigation of all crops is assured by the Delta, Zifta and Asriont Barrages, though the durah crops must necessarily be late. In Upper Egypt the conditions are far from favorable and indicate a flood similar, if not inferior, to that of 1902.

div.head: CRICKET.
ALEXANDRIA v. CAIRO STAFF & DEPTS.
div.p: A cricket match was played on the Alexandria ground on Saturday afternoon between the Alexandria Cricket Club and the Cairo Staff and Depts., resulting in an easy win for the former. The notable feature of the match was the excellent batting of Mainprice for Alexandria, who gained a complete mastery over the ball and just topped the century by _ pretty and faultless play. A useful contribution of 42 not out was also made by McLean, who drove with considerable force, and 8. R. Carver, who had 58 to ‘his credit, also gave an ex- CellNet exhibition of hard hitting. Prosser, H. B. Carver, and Barnard were responsible for the dismissal of the Cairo team for 125 runs, the first named taking 3 wickets for 29 runs, the second 2 for 42, and the third 3 for 19. For the Staff and Depts. Jordan dismissed six of the Alexandria team and gave far more trouble than any of the bowlers, bent when Mainprice had broken the backbone of the bowling the others players indulged in slogging and ran not a few risks. div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: Un succeeds aprés l’autre. La terrasse du Casino était de nouveau comble pour les concerts d’hier, le matin comme |’aprésmidi. Il n’y a en effet rien de mieux pour passer une journée trés agréablement. Concert, chanteurs et cinématographe, tout était parfait. Le grand festival Wagner est donc fixé pour dimanche prochain a 11 heures du matin.

Les pierres sont divisées en lots de 20 4 100m3. Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d’enchére de 1% et ' déposer le 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral 4 la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour del’adjudication. Ils auront 4 supporter les droits de carritre au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de (10) dix jours sous peine de folle enchére pour compte de l’adjudicataire et sous perte du dépdt de 10 %. div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujour@ hui @ 11h, 1/2 am).

Le marché. n’a pas présenté ce matin la méme animation que vendredi dernier et la cote a été moins soutenue pour les valeurs dirigeantes, mais la tendance, s'il faut en croire la généralité des intéressés, -demeure ferme avec unedemande de bon augure pour l’avenir. Il y a des acheteurs, dit-on, et en général ils doivent payer un prix supérieur & celui coté. Bref, les acheteurs affluent, tandis que les ven- deurs se sont éclipsés. Nous avons déjA signalé trop de fois les raisons qui déterminent ces revirements haussiers chaque fin de mois pour y revenir.

Les affaires ont porté spécialement sur Agricole, qui a cloturé offerte 4 7 7/8 et sur la National Bank qui a perdu 1/4 de livre & 19 3/16. La Daira Sanieh a, an contraire, gagné 1/4 de livre 4 14 1/8 et. PObligation Crédit Foncier 5 fr. l’ancienne 4 306 et 8 fr. 50 la nouvelle 4 264 1/2. La Delta Light a été inscrite A 9 1/2 ex coupon.

En ce qui concerne |’Obligation Crédit Fon- cier, la hausse ininterrompue dont ce titre bénéficie depuis quelques jours serait occa} sionnée, sil faut en croire un bruit acerédité en bourse, & un découvert qu’on cherche a égorger. Si ce bruit est fondé, il est probable que le recul,constaté récemment sera totale- ment regagné, et au-deld.

Une autre valeur qui progresse de fagon inattendue, aprés de longs mois de baisse et de marasme, c’est la Building Lands dont le prix remonte d’un coup de 2 1/16 & 2 7/16-1/2. La raison qu’on allégue pour cette reprisa soudaine est le rachat par la société elle-méme de ses titres dépréciés, |
En hausse encore les Tramways d’Alexan- drie de 136 4 137 les Privilégiées et de 280 i 282 les Dividendes, |’Alexandria Water de 10 5/8 & 10 3/4, la Land Bank de 6 13/16 a 7 1/16.

Parmiles petites valeurs la Delta Land, trés soutenue, s’avance de 1 7/16 4 1 1/2, Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 20/9 4 21, PAnglo-Egyptian Allotment de 1 7/8 4 2 l’action et de 50 4 60 P.T. la part de fondateur, les Cotton Ginners de 11/4 41 5/16, et la Levico de 1/4 a 5/16. Lia part de fondateur de cette dernitre s’inscrit 4 4 livres. On achéte la fondateur Unitedal 3/4.
En revanche, les Nungovich Hotels revien- nent de 14 4 13, l’action nouvelle Comptoir de 25/164 21/4, Union Fonciére de 4 1/2 a 4 7/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/16 a 4.
Les Estates sont trés sontenus A 1/2-9/16. La Cassa di Sconto reprend: de 25 & 26.
Le reste de la cote demeure sans changement.

Ainsi que nous l’avons déja dit au début de ce bulletin, bien que l’ensemble dela cote ne soit pas aussi satisfaisant que vendredi der- nier, l’impression générale est meilleure. Les acheteurs ne s’esquivent pas de facon aussi absolue que naguére et si pour certains titres, comme la National Bank, ‘les transactions ne s’effectuent qu’au prix d’une réduction, pour d’autres, au contraire, les acquéreurs acceptent de payer un surplus.
Le tout est desavoirs’il nes’agit pas d’un simple découvert ou d’une réaction passa- gére, ou si p aIIHOEREON est appelde & ce consolider.

div.head: HAUGUE CONFERENCE
ABOLITION OF CONTRABAND
DIVERGENCE OF OPINION
div.p: The Hague, July 27.

The Conference debated the British proposal regarding the abolition of contraband, which was opposed by France, Russia, United States, aid Germany, who urged the framing ofa list of contraband articles. Lord Reay express- ed surprise at the attitude of the United States, quoting American state documents showing that the United States, formerly urged the abolition of contraband. Lord Reay declared that it was impossible to separate absolute contraband from relative. General Porter, replying-to Lord Reay, said that he preferred the modern policy of President Roosevelt to the ancient and out-of-date poliey quoted by Lord Reay. ( Reuter)

div.head: ROYAL IRISH CONSTABULARY
div.p: A MUTINOUS MEETING.

Brirast, July 28. 500 men of the Royal Irish Constabulary at an excitéd meeting in the barrack square resolved to demand a _permanent increase in .pay of a shilling a day, an increase in pensions, and the right to discuss grievan- ces whenever they please. Crowds of cheer- ing towns people invaded the barracks and earried the ringleader on sheir shoul- ders to the Custom House where he harangued the crowd, amid the cheers of the populace, including the strikers, (Aeuter)

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
